title: Embraer's Strategic Win with SAS: A Catalyst for Sustainable Growth and Market Dominance
description:
Technological Leadership in Fuel Efficiency: A Competitive Moat The E195-E2's Pratt & Whitney GTF engines deliver a 29% improvement in fuel efficiency over legacy aircraft, a figure that cannot be understated in an era of volatile fuel prices.
Sustainability as a Sales Driver: Aligning with ESG Trends The E195-E2's compatibility with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is a game-changer.
ESG Alignment: Sustainable aviation credentials attract ESG-focused capital, a growing segment of global equity flows.
The backlog's steady expansion signals robust demand, with the SAS order pushing it to record levels—a positive sign for revenue visibility and investor confidence.
For investors seeking exposure to a sustainable aviation leader, ERJ/EMBR3 offers compelling upside ahead of Q3 earnings, especially as the world transitions to a low-carbon future.
text:
In a landmark deal that underscores its technological prowess, Embraer has secured a $4 billion order from Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) for 45 firm E195-E2 aircraft, alongside options for 10 more. This agreement not only marks SAS's largest direct jet order from a manufacturer since 1996 but also positions Embraer as a leader in sustainable aviation—a critical edge in an industry grappling with decarbonization mandates and fleet modernization demands. The order signals a strategic shift in how airlines prioritize fuel efficiency and environmental impact, while offering investors a compelling entry point into Embraer's stock ahead of its Q3 2025 earnings.

Technological Leadership in Fuel Efficiency: A Competitive Moat

The E195-E2's Pratt & Whitney GTF engines deliver a 29% improvement in fuel efficiency over legacy aircraft, a figure that cannot be understated in an era of volatile fuel prices. For SAS, this translates to lower operational costs and a smaller carbon footprint—key priorities as European regulators tighten emissions standards. While competitors like Airbus's A220 offer longer ranges, the E195-E2's optimal size and efficiency make it ideal for SAS's dense regional and European networks. This specificity highlights Embraer's ability to tailor solutions for airlines seeking balance between capacity and cost, a niche it's leveraging to carve out market share in the single-aisle segment.

Sustainability as a Sales Driver: Aligning with ESG Trends

The E195-E2's compatibility with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is a game-changer. Current blends of up to 50% SAF are operational, and certification for 100% SAF is in progress—a feature that directly aligns with SAS's goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2040. Embraer's emphasis on reducing noise pollution (62% quieter than older models) and emissions positions it as a partner for airlines under scrutiny for their environmental impact. As ESG criteria increasingly influence investment and procurement decisions, this edge becomes a defensible competitive advantage.

Investors can observe that ERJ has outperformed Airbus over this period, reflecting market recognition of its niche strengths and sustainable growth trajectory.

Fleet Renewal Tailwinds: A Global Opportunity

The SAS deal is part of a broader trend as airlines retire older, less efficient aircraft. With a 12% increase in its commercial aircraft backlog and revenue visibility through 2031, Embraer is securing a stable production pipeline. The E2 series' appeal extends beyond Europe: Mexicana's recent delivery of E190-E2 and E195-E2 aircraft underscores the model's global utility for expanding connectivity while adhering to environmental standards. For investors, this points to a sustained order flow as carriers worldwide modernize fleets to meet passenger demand and regulatory demands.

Investment Thesis: ERJ/EMBR3 as a Buy with Upside Ahead

Embraer's stock (NYSE: ERJ; B3: EMBR3) is primed for growth. Key catalysts include:

1. Q3 2025 Earnings: Expected to reflect strong backlog execution and margin improvements driven by the SAS order's $4 billion contribution.

2. ESG Alignment: Sustainable aviation credentials attract ESG-focused capital, a growing segment of global equity flows.

3. Market Share Gains: The E2 series' proven performance and scalability could accelerate orders from carriers seeking midsize jets in Asia, Latin America, and Africa.

The backlog's steady expansion signals robust demand, with the SAS order pushing it to record levels—a positive sign for revenue visibility and investor confidence.

Risks and Considerations

While the SAS deal is a triumph, Embraer faces execution risks, including supply chain constraints and delays in 100% SAF certification. Competitor pricing strategies, particularly from Airbus, could also pressure margins. However, the company's focus on niche efficiency and sustainability—rather than broad-market competition—mitigates these risks.

Conclusion: A Strategic Buy with Long-Term Momentum

Embraer's win with SAS is more than a sales milestone—it's a validation of its ability to innovate in a sector demanding both environmental stewardship and economic viability. With a growing backlog, a product line aligned with global decarbonization goals, and a focus on midsize aircraft that competitors overlook, Embraer is well-positioned to capitalize on fleet modernization trends. For investors seeking exposure to a sustainable aviation leader, ERJ/EMBR3 offers compelling upside ahead of Q3 earnings, especially as the world transitions to a low-carbon future.

This is a buy with a horizon stretching well beyond 2025.

title: SAS places largest jet order since 1996 with 55 Embraer E195-E2 aircraft to drive sustainable growth
description:
Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) has ordered 45 Embraer E195-E2 aircraft with options for 10 more, marking its largest aircraft order since 1996.
The E195-E2 aircraft will improve SAS’s operational flexibility, lower trip costs, and allow for increased flight frequencies across Scandinavia and Europe.
SAS CEO Anko van der Werff praised the aircraft’s fuel efficiency, comfort, and lower emissions, calling the investment “a defining moment” for the airline’s future.
The E195-E2, powered by Pratt & Whitney’s PW1900G engines, offers 29% better fuel efficiency and a 62% lower noise footprint compared to older jets.
The E2 has already been tested with 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and is on track for full SAF certification, aligning with SAS’s climate goals.
text:
Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) has ordered 45 Embraer E195-E2 aircraft with options for 10 more, marking its largest aircraft order since 1996. Valued at approximately $4 billion, this deal is a major step in SAS’s fleet renewal strategy, focused on enhancing efficiency, sustainability, and regional connectivity, especially through its Copenhagen hub.

Deliveries will begin in late 2027 and continue over four years. The E195-E2 aircraft will improve SAS’s operational flexibility, lower trip costs, and allow for increased flight frequencies across Scandinavia and Europe.

SAS CEO Anko van der Werff praised the aircraft’s fuel efficiency, comfort, and lower emissions, calling the investment “a defining moment” for the airline’s future. The E195-E2, powered by Pratt & Whitney’s PW1900G engines, offers 29% better fuel efficiency and a 62% lower noise footprint compared to older jets.

The E2 has already been tested with 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and is on track for full SAF certification, aligning with SAS’s climate goals.

The order, supported by Skyworks Holding, reinforces SAS’s position as a sustainability leader and comes as the airline ranks #1 globally for on-time performance in April and May 2025 (Cirium).

text:
METHANOL-TO-JET FUEL MARKET OVERVIEW

The global methanol-to-Jet fuel market size was USD 1.31 billion in 2025 and is projected to reach USD 8.54 billion by 2033, exhibiting a CAGR of 3.3% during the forecast period.

Methanol-to-jet (MTJF) is becoming one of the most important innovations in the quest to make aviation sustainable worldwide. Since the aviation industry has a major share in global carbon emission, research on more synthetic and sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs) such as methanol-derived ones has taken a high profile. The fuel conversion feedstock requires natural gas, biomass or even CO 2 and H 2 gas captured to create Methanol, as it is a low cost and versatile method of producing fuel. The MTJF process applies sophisticated catalytic and thermochemical technologies to methanol that convert the fuel to a hydrocarbon that is suitable to the jet fuel specifications. The main growth factors in this market are incremental pressure on the aviation industry to go green, friendly government policies and development in fuel production technology. Besides, the methanol-to-jet fuel is becoming very popular because it would not require many modifications as it would be compatible with the existing infrastructure and engines. As traffic in the airline industry and demand of eco-friendly aviation alternatives has been increasing, there has been a strong research and developmental work, as well as demonstrations of pilot scales all over the world. In North America, Europe, and Asia, expectations run high because these regions have been able to establish good networks in aviation, embrace renewable energy, and provide monetary aid. Nevertheless, the main challenges are commercial scalability, expensive production, and regulations compliance. Nevertheless, collaborations between the energy companies, airlines and research centers are expediting the commercialization process. All in all, the methanol-to-jet fuel market is the market with huge growth opportunities, becoming a sustainable solution in the field of sustainable aviation fuel that will play a central role in the process of turning aviation to net-zero emissions by the mid-century.

METHANOL-TO-JET FUEL MARKET KEY FINDING

Market Size and Growth: International, methanol-to-jet market size was expected to be USD 1.31 billion in the year 2024, expecting to rise to USD 2.52 billion by 2033 by CAGR of 8.54 percent.

Key Market Driver: In an effort to increase its growth in the global Methanol-to-Jet (MTJ) fuel market which is expected to scale by USD 2.5 billion in 2032 compared to USD 500 million in 2023, the global Methanol-to-Jet fuel market will be fuelled by the rising awareness of the capacity of methanol as a corpulent stock to generate jet fuel and the growing force of sustainable aviation fuel (SAFs).

Major Market Restraint: The large capital outflow to be made initially to set up a MTJ fuel manufacturing facility is a great hindrance and it is estimated that the cost of a commercial size MTJ plant would shrink north of USD 100 million that too it is estimated it can deter new entrants in the market.

Emerging Trends: Airbus in association with HIF Global has started testing methanol-to-jet fuel technologies in India in order to make aviation emissions up to 80 percent lower than the conventional jet fuel.

Regional Leadership: Morocco has become a sustainability agenda in the region of MENA in sustainable aviation fuel productions with its plans to produce more than 100m liters of SAF by 2030.

Competitive Landscape: ExxonMobil has an estimated 30 percent of the market share in the MTJ fuel niche due to its unique process that enables it to produce synthetic jet fuel blending components using methanol with a selectivity rate of more than 90 percent.

Market Segmentation: On a feedstock basis, natural gas, on MTJ fuel production capacity is 40 per cent, biomass about 35 per cent, and the remaining 25 per cent is coal and waste products worldwide.

Recent Development: The Union Marine Management Services installed the NAPA Voyage Optimization system on 55 bulk carriers, which is on course to save more than 5-10 tons per vessel greenhouse emissions per year.

GLOBAL CRISES IMPACTING METHANOL-TO-JET FUEL MARKET

COVID-19 IMPACT

Methanol-to-Jet Fuel Market Had a Negative Effect Due to Supply Chain Disruption During COVID-19 Pandemic

The global COVID-19 pandemic has been unprecedented and staggering, with the market experiencing lower-than-anticipated demand across all regions compared to pre-pandemic levels. The sudden market growth reflected by the rise in CAGR is attributable to the market’s growth and demand returning to pre-pandemic levels.

The commercialization and development of the methanol-to-jet fuel market share was affected greatly due to the presence of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, with the world aviation set to a virtual standstill by travel restrictions, lockdowns, and declining passenger numbers, investment in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) development, including the methanol based variety, was put on the backburner. Disparity in the supply chains and reduced access to labs, as well as reallocation of funds toward pandemic-related programs, hindered research and development. Further, in the beginning stages of the pandemic, oil became more affordable, thus weakening the economic motivation to switch to other fuels instead of conventional jet fuel. Major industrial partnerships and pilot projects were also delayed in the effort to adapt operations to pandemic inevitable. On top of that, the general decrease in the air traffic diverted the urgency of the decarbonization process in the aviation industry. Incentives and policies via the government to encourage SAF use also experienced temporary hindrances as the world pre-occupied itself in grappling the public health crisis and the economic comeback. Combined, all these obstacles decelerated the pace of the market development of methanol-to-jet fuel and postponed both timelines and technology upscaling. Yet, with the post-pandemic revival the sustainable aviation has made a comeback with governments and businesses aiming to construct a more energy resilient, but cleaner environment with the methanol-to-jet fuel market having a rebound potential in the medium term.

LATEST TREND

Integration of Green Hydrogen with Methanol Pathways Enhancing Jet Fuel Sustainability Drives Market Growth

One of the emerging trends can transform the methanol-to- jet fuel sector is the involvement of green hydrogen in the methanol manufacturing process that enhances the sustainability and carbon intensity of the end product (fuel) quite remarkably. Historically, natural gas could be used to make methanol (gray methanol), however, in order to meet net-zero targets the industry is transitioning to methanol made by using captured CO2 and renewable sources of hydrogen- also made via electrolysis in renewable energy. This is a cleaner source of green methanol to be used to synthesize jet fuel. This trend is associated with the worldwide decarbonization and is to comply with the international standards of aviation fuel emissions, e.g., CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation). Power-to-Liquid (PtL) is another area rapidly gaining investment among the companies, in which green hydrogen and CO 2 are converted into methanol and then undergo catalytic conversion to become jet fuel. Europe and North America Notable projects are also underway in Europe and North America to investigate integrated facilities to incorporate electrolysis units, CO 2 capture technologies and FischerTropsch synthesis or alternative advanced conversion technologies. Such convergence is not only improved sustainability, but also offers a strategic solution on hydrogen storage and hydrogen transport through methanol. With the green hydrogen and SAF gaining policy support, their tendency is expected to spark future investments, collaboration and expansion of the methanol-to-jet fuel ecosystem.

Methanol-to-Jet Fuel Market SEGMENTATION

BY TYPE

Based on type, the global market can be categorized into Methanol, jet fuel additives, conversion technology

Methanol: Methanol is a versatile chemical and energy carrier manufactured out of natural gas, biomass or captured CO 2. It is an essential petrochemical as a feedstock to methanol-to-jet fuel. The fact that it is adaptable makes it appropriate in the synthesis of renewable fuels.

Jet Fuel Additives: They are the chemical substances that are mixed with jet fuel to enhance their quantity or reduce emissions or enhance safety. Additives assist to achieve strict aviation fuels in MTJF. They said the properties in cold-flow and oxidation stability.

Conversion Technology: Catalytic processes include FischerTropsch synthesis and methanol-to-olefins (MTO) and oligomerization. The technologies make methanol to be converted to amicable hydrocarbons to meet the aviation fuel. The breakthrough here will be innovation, which will help to drive down costs and scale.

BY APPLICATION

Based on Application, the global market can be categorized into Aviation, transportation, energy industry

Aviation: The aviation sector is the main end user of the jet fuel produced out of methanol and is struggling to decarbonize. Open-loop SAFs such as MTJF are drop-in compatible with combustion engines and current assets, which enables low-emission air travel.

Transportation: MTJF also contributes to increased prospects of transportation in general, offering cleaner fueling in such areas as cargo and logistics. It increases energy security and decreases the economic dependence on oil imports.

Energy Industry: Is at the heart of providing methanol and scaling fuel synthesis technologies. The shift of the energy sector towards non fossil energy sources is driving seeding of investment in synthetic fuels such as MTJF.

MARKET DYNAMICS

Market dynamics include driving and restraining factors, opportunities and challenges stating the market conditions.

DRIVING FACTORS

Stringent Emission Regulations in Aviation Industry Boost the Market

The trend towards decreasing the carbon footprint of the aviation industry is mounting pressure on the industry as the global emissions are increasing and regulatory requirements are becoming stringent to methanol-to-jet fuel market growth. International organizations such as ICAO, IATA have proposed the objectives of carbon-neutral growth and net-zero emissions in the long term. Policies like the CORSIA and national policies to blend SAFs are forcing airlines and fuel suppliers to use non-emitting fuels that include methanol-to-jet fuel. The use of methanol-based fuels provides a high level of attraction because they are able to comply with the requirements of the strict emission standards required in the aviation industry besides being highly compatible with the current infrastructure in terms of drops. Such regulatory frameworks not only prove that stakeholders in the aviation industry are being coerced into using alternative aviation fuels but also warrant government investment and privates financing in SAF research and development. Therefore, emission compliance becomes another major driver that contributes to the introduction and evolution of the technologies of the MTJF.

Increasing Investment in Sustainable Aviation Fuels Expand the Market

Investments in SAF are also on the rise as sustainability now appears as a priority of governments and companies. As an emerging SAF route, methanol-to-jet fuel is enjoying this shift. Taking a big bet with their investment: Major energy companies, chemical giant, and even aviation have directed huge capital investment on SAF infrastructure, such as methanol manufactories, CO2 capture and conversion plants and fuel conversion plants. The market is also driven by public-private partnerships, grants and subsidies in the form of R&D and clean energy. The ability to use methanol as a variety of feedstock and a relatively developed chain of production supply makes it high-interest investment. The long-term growth potential also attracts the attention of investors by the search of airlines exploring reliable, low-carbon fuel options. With the growth of capital flows, the market of the MTJF is becoming discussed more promptly in terms of commercialization and global pilot projects, which is the indicator of its appearance in the zone of central significance in the SAF ecosystem.

RESTRAINING FACTOR

High Production Costs and Commercialization Barriers Potentially Impede Market Growth

However, the methanol-to-jet fuel market is under the challenge of its major headwind which happens to be expensive production and capital. The conversion of methanol to jet fuel are energy-intensive, complex catalytic processes not yet cost competitive with conventional fuels. In addition, green methanol production by utilizing green hydrogen and CO 2, which are renewable sources of methanol, introduces additional costs (the cost of electrolysis technology and carbon capture technology is high). Upscaling of such processes, whether lab or pilot scale to commercial scale involves enormous finance in terms of infrastructure and long reproduction schedules. Also, the policy certainty or subsidies that will regulate the production cost will be minimal and the investment will be risky. All these economic and technical barriers hamper the rapidity with which the market can attain the economies of scale rendering adoption into a potential problem in the short term.

OPPORTUNITY

Leveraging CO₂ Utilization for Carbon-Neutral Fuel Production Create Opportunity for The Product in The Market

Methanol-to-jet fuel is an original way to pass the methane fuel through the transformation of CO 2 gases into jet fuel products that are valuable and practical. Rather than letting the CO 2 languish somewhere, this mechanism, which recycles the carbon, entails a combination of CO 2 with green hydrogen, to manufacture methanol, which would then be converted into aviation fuel, allowing the industries, not just to eliminate a couple of greenhouse gases, but also to acquire adequate fuel to address their needs. The method is consistent with the idea of circular carbon economy and contributes to the climate agenda. With increasing numbers of carbon pricing and emission trading systems it is economically feasible to utilize CO 2. Therefore, jet fuel made of methanol will have a twofold effect, namely, decarbonizing the aviation sector and giving an effective, profitable disposal of industrial emissions of CO 2. Due to increased interest in carbon capture and storage (CCS), methanol-to-jet fuel might be a linkage between emissions reduction and energy transition.

CHALLENGE

Regulatory Certification and Fuel Standard Compliance Could Be a Potential Challenge for Consumers

Getting regulatory certification and full commercial use is one of the key challenges facing the methanol-to-jet fuel market. Controls Aviation fuels have to meet strict international specifications, e.g. ASTM D7566, to guarantee performance, safety and compliance with aircraft engines. This many-staged process of turning methanol presents a challenge of proving an equivalence to petroleum-based fuels. These processes are testing, evaluation, and approval that may delay the implementation of MTJF technologies. Also, the standard-setting organizations and government aviation regulators frequently demand field tests and many years of performance data. This regulatory logjam may discourage the early investors and deter the market entry, even though it proves beneficial to the environment. Combating these certification hazards will necessitate intensive cooperation amid aviation agencies, standards organizations as well as fuel producers.

Methanol-to-Jet Fuel Market REGIONAL INSIGHTS

NORTH AMERICA

North America will have a dominant role in the United State methanol-to-jet fuel market because of its developed aviation sector, developed methanol infrastructure, and the advanced scope of clean energy innovation. The U.S Department of Energy and other federal agencies have initiated SAF granting programs and tax credits as an incentive to production. Firms such as Carbon Recycling International and Air Company are coming up with methanol-based fuels and carbon exploitation technology in the area. There are also a number of pilot and demonstration projects undertaken by the U.S. in liaison with research institutions and giant airlines. Besides, North America has an extensive natural gas and renewable energy capacity, which supposes a variety of feedstocks used in the methanol production in the region. North America is a leading center of growth in methanol-to-jet fuel industry since its success has been attributable to the availability of robust policy backing, research and development capacities and energy supplies.

EUROPE

Europe is at the forefront in the implementation of sustainable aviation fuel and the vigorous climate policy pursued include the European Green Deal and Fit for 55 package. According to the EU renewable energy directive (RED II), more advanced biofuel must be used, such as synthetic fuels using synthetics, such as jet fuel made of methanol. Multiple nations of Europe are also setting up much investment into the infrastructure of green hydrogen and CO2 capture to accompany renewable methanol. Such countries as Germany, the Netherlands, and Denmark are establishing large-scale Power-to-Liquid (PtL) plants to provide SAF to the key airports. Availability of the advanced aviation OEMs and the regulatory bodies as well enables swift rates in certification in the region. As airline sustainability initiatives increase and international efforts are made to work together, Europe will probably continue to lead what happens in the methanol-to-jet fuel sector.

ASIA

Asian market is becoming a major player in the market of methanol to jet fuel due to its flourishing aviation industry and its growing interest in clean energy transition. China, which is the largest methanol manufacturer in the world, is using its experience to seek methanol-based SAF. In the meantime, other states, such as Japan and South Korea, are betting on green hydrogen and carbon capture processes, which can be used to feed an industry producing methanol. Furthermore, India is also exploring other fuel options to make its aviation sector decarbonized within its National Bioenergy Mission. Regional governments are also making public-private partnerships to create SAF supply chains, whereas Asian airlines are engaging in strategic agreements to purchase SAF in future. The presence of cheap renewables and the increasingly serious attitude towards the reduction of emissions make Asia one of the key areas to scale down methanol-to-jet fuel solutions.

KEY INDUSTRY PLAYERS

Key Industry Players Shaping the Market Through Innovation and Market Expansion

The methanol-to-jet fuel business landscape is characterized by multinationals in the energy sector, stakeholders in the aviation industry and new technology companies that are accelerating alternatives to jet fuel in aviation. Other major companies are Carbon Recycling International (Iceland) that has debuted CO 2-to-methanol conversion technology into the process of jet fuel production. Another interesting feature of Air Company (USA) is the development of carbon-negative jet fuel based on the CO 2 captured and renewable electricity. The European firms such as Nordic Blue Crude and Sunfire GmbH are investing in the Power-to-Liquid solution that involves the production of green hydrogen combined with methanol synthesis in aviation fuel. ExxonMobil and Shell are also looking at developing methanol and synthetic fuel avenues in their decarbonization plans. China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) is using methanol knowledge in innovation of SAF in Asia. Moreover, such aerospace companies as Airbus and Boeing are engaging with SAF manufacturers to hasten the certification and incorporation of methanol-derived fuels. Such players are engaging in strategic partnerships, joining demonstration projects, and accessing such government funds to come up with scale and cost effective MTJF solutions.

List Of Top Methanol-to-Jet Fuel Market Companies

Honeywell (U.S.)

HIF Global (Chile)

ETFuels (Ireland)

Topsoe (Denmark)

KEY INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT

March 2024: Air Company announced the successful demonstration of its CO₂-to-methanol-to-jet fuel process at a pilot plant in New York, with backing from the U.S. Department of Defense and JetBlue Ventures.

REPORT COVERAGE

The methanol-to-jet fuel sector is at the nexus between climate innovation and aviation transition and it provides an exciting pathway to decarbonize one of the hardest areas to decarbonize. Due to the increasing global demand in air travel coupled with a stricter set of environmental regulations, there has never been a greater necessity to find ways of establishing sustainable and scalable aviation fuels. Because of its high efficiency and easy flexibility to produce, methanol is a good resource to use as a source of jet fuel, especially when renewable sources or captured carbon is used. The technological progressing areas that can contribute to the MTJF process are catalytic conversion, integration of green hydrogen, and CO 2 utilization. Despite being at an early stage of commercialization, there is an indication of robust up-ward growth because of growing investments, regulatory backing, and pilot demonstrations are being allowed. Other regions such as North America, Europe, and Asia are making critical action to ensure the creation of an infrastructure, innovation and adoption alike via policy mandate and partnership. Nevertheless, high costs of production, certification barriers, and readiness in infrastructure have remained as some of the drawbacks in the market. Nevertheless, the methanol-to-jet fuel represents an excellent chance to make the aircraft sector more environmentally friendly and reduce the number of emissions released into the environment. As long as the innovation continues, the collaboration between nations exists, and communities of public-private investors, the MTJF market is bound to become a foundation of the sustainable aviation fuel environment in the future.

title: British Airways signs multi-year deal with EcoCeres to reduce emission by 400000 tonnes
description:
British Airways has entered into a new long-term agreement with Hong Kong-based biofuels producer EcoCeres to supply sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) made from waste-based biomass feedstock, the companies announced today.
Under the agreement, the SAF provided by EcoCeres is expected to reduce British Airways’ fuel lifecycle carbon emissions by around 400,000 metric tonnes.
EcoCeres, which specializes in producing biofuels and bioproducts from biomass, creates SAF from 100% waste-based materials like used cooking oil.
“We are proud to partner with British Airways in this strategic agreement to jointly tackle greenhouse gas emissions in aviation,” said Matti Lievonen, CEO of EcoCeres.
This new agreement with EcoCeres is another important step toward our goal of reaching net zero by 2050.”
text:
British Airways has entered into a new long-term agreement with Hong Kong-based biofuels producer EcoCeres to supply sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) made from waste-based biomass feedstock, the companies announced today. The deal is aimed at helping the airline move closer to its environmental goals, including reducing emissions and increasing the use of cleaner fuels, reports ESGtoday.

Under the agreement, the SAF provided by EcoCeres is expected to reduce British Airways’ fuel lifecycle carbon emissions by around 400,000 metric tonnes. That’s equivalent to the emissions from flying approximately 240,000 economy class passengers on return trips between London and New York.

EcoCeres, which specializes in producing biofuels and bioproducts from biomass, creates SAF from 100% waste-based materials like used cooking oil. This fuel offers a carbon emission reduction of up to 80% compared to traditional jet fuel.

“We are proud to partner with British Airways in this strategic agreement to jointly tackle greenhouse gas emissions in aviation,” said Matti Lievonen, CEO of EcoCeres. “Our commitment to sustainability is unwavering, and this partnership shows our focus on offering fuel solutions that help the aviation industry meet its climate goals.”

British Airways’ parent company, International Airlines Group (IAG), has committed to using 10% SAF by 2030—equivalent to 1 million tonnes of fuel per year—and achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. In 2023, IAG’s airlines used about 12% of the global SAF supply and have already secured one-third of the SAF needed to meet their 2030 target.

Carrie Harris, British Airways’ Director of Sustainability, highlighted the role of SAF in the airline’s broader climate efforts: “In 2024, SAF made up 2.7% of our total fuel use and has helped us cut our carbon intensity by 13% since 2019. This new agreement with EcoCeres is another important step toward our goal of reaching net zero by 2050.”

title: Sustainability in Aviation: Fuel, Tech & Industry Insights
description:
The Environmental Impact of Aviation Emissions Breakdown Aviation accounts for about 2-3% of global CO₂ emissions.
That might sound modest, but here's the kicker: aviation emissions have surged 150% since the 1990s, driven by our insatiable appetite for air travel.
Sustainable Aviation Fuel is chemically nearly identical to conventional jet fuel, but it's produced from renewable resources instead of fossil crude oil.
Hydrogen Power Hydrogen aircraft burn hydrogen fuel cells or direct combustion engines, producing only water vapor as exhaust—no CO₂ at all.
R&D funding is flowing into breakthrough technologies: NASA's Advanced Air Mobility program is investing hundreds of millions in electric and hydrogen aircraft development.
text:
Aviation is at the crossroads of innovation and environmental responsibility, and the path forward isn't as straightforward as most people think.

This article cuts through the noise to show you what's actually happening with sustainable aviation; from the fuel breakthroughs that are scaling faster than expected to the quantum-powered simulations that are revolutionizing how we optimize flight operations.

You'll walk away with a clear picture of where the industry stands and what tools are making the biggest difference right now.

Let's dive into the technologies and strategies that are actually moving the needle on aviation sustainability.

The Environmental Impact of Aviation

Emissions Breakdown

Aviation accounts for about 2-3% of global CO₂ emissions. Roughly 915 million tonnes annually as of 2019. That might sound modest, but here's the kicker: aviation emissions have surged 150% since the 1990s, driven by our insatiable appetite for air travel. The industry is growing fast, and without intervention, these numbers would keep climbing.

But CO₂ isn't the whole story when it comes to aviation's climate impact. NOx emissions, water vapor, and those wispy contrails you see streaking across the sky all contribute to warming effects. These non-CO₂ factors can actually double or triple aviation's total climate contribution compared to CO₂ alone.

Industry Comparison

Want some perspective on where aviation sits in the emissions landscape? Here's how it stacks up:

Shipping: About 3% of global emissions—slightly higher than aviation but serving different transport needs

Road Transport: Around 12% of global emissions—cars and trucks still dominate the transport sector

Power Generation: Roughly 25% of global emissions—the biggest single contributor by far

Buildings: About 6% of global emissions—including heating, cooling, and construction

Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) and Its Potential

What Is SAF?

Sustainable Aviation Fuel is chemically nearly identical to conventional jet fuel, but it's produced from renewable resources instead of fossil crude oil. Think of it as a drop-in replacement, you can use it in existing aircraft engines without modifications, which is why airlines love it.

The magic happens in how it's made: from waste cooking oil, agricultural residues, algae, or even captured carbon dioxide.

SAF can reduce lifecycle carbon emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional jet fuel. The key word here is "lifecycle"—this accounts for everything from feedstock production to combustion in the engine.

Current Usage & Barriers

Electric and Hydrogen-Powered Aircraft

Electric Aviation

Electric aircraft are already taking off—literally—for short regional flights and pilot training. Companies like Eviation and Heart Aerospace have electric planes in testing that can handle 200-500 mile routes with 9-19 passengers. The technology works beautifully for these shorter hops, offering near-zero emissions and significantly lower operating costs.

But here's the reality check: battery weight and energy density remain major limitations. Current lithium-ion batteries are still too heavy for long-haul flights, though breakthroughs in solid-state batteries could change that equation within the next decade.

Hydrogen Power

Hydrogen aircraft burn hydrogen fuel cells or direct combustion engines, producing only water vapor as exhaust—no CO₂ at all. Airbus is leading the charge with their ZEROe concept aircraft, targeting commercial hydrogen flights by 2035. The technology is promising for medium-haul flights up to about 2,000 miles.

The infrastructure challenge is massive, though: airports need entirely new fuel storage, handling, and distribution systems. Hydrogen also requires about four times the storage volume of jet fuel, which means significant aircraft redesigns.

Expected commercial timelines look like this:

2025-2027: Regional hydrogen aircraft (9-19 seats) enter service

2030-2032: Short-haul hydrogen planes (50-100 seats) begin commercial operations

2035-2040: Medium-haul hydrogen aircraft (100+ seats) reach market maturity

Operational Improvements and Carbon Offsetting

Smarter Flight Operations

Airlines are getting incredibly sophisticated about operational efficiency—optimizing flight paths, reducing aircraft weight, and using AI to minimize fuel burn. Modern flight management systems can calculate the most fuel-efficient routes in real-time, accounting for weather, air traffic, and aircraft performance. Some airlines are seeing 3-5% fuel savings just from smarter route planning.

BQPSim's quantum-inspired simulation tools are revolutionizing this space by helping airlines optimize operations at unprecedented scale and speed.

Our QIEO-powered solvers can process complex multi-variable optimization problems—like simultaneous route planning, crew scheduling, and maintenance coordination—up to 20 times faster than classical methods.

This means airlines can make real-time adjustments that reduce fuel usage and minimize emissions across their entire fleet operations.

Weight reduction is another big win: removing just one pound from an aircraft can save about $3,000 in fuel costs annually. Airlines are switching to lighter seats, digital manuals instead of paper, and even redesigning meal service equipment.

Airport Sustainability

Airports are becoming powerhouses of renewable energy adoption, with solar farms and wind installations becoming standard features. Denver International Airport, for example, generates enough solar power to offset 6% of its total energy consumption.

Ground support equipment is rapidly electrifying—those baggage tugs and aircraft pushback vehicles you see on the tarmac are increasingly battery-powered.

Here are some standout airport sustainability initiatives:

Copenhagen Airport: Carbon-neutral since 2009, now targeting carbon-negative operations by 2030

San Francisco International: Zero waste to landfill program and 100% renewable electricity

Amsterdam Schiphol: Installing massive heat pump systems to eliminate natural gas usage

Seattle-Tacoma International: Using biofuels for ground vehicle fleets and sustainable construction materials

Carbon Offsets

Carbon offsets let passengers and airlines invest in projects that remove or prevent CO₂ emissions elsewhere—like reforestation, renewable energy projects, or direct air capture facilities.

The idea is simple: if you can't eliminate your flight emissions, you can pay to eliminate an equivalent amount somewhere else. Many airlines now offer offset programs at checkout, and some build offsetting into their ticket prices automatically.

But here's where it gets tricky: offset quality varies dramatically, and many projects don't deliver the promised emissions reductions. Critics argue that offsets can become a way to avoid making harder changes to actual operations.

Regulatory and Industry-Wide Commitments

International Agreements

The Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) is the world's first global market-based measure for any industry sector. Starting in 2021, it requires airlines to offset emissions growth above 2020 levels through verified carbon credits. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) oversees the program, which covers about 77% of international aviation activity.

CORSIA is designed as a bridge measure while the industry develops longer-term sustainability solutions. It's not perfect, but it creates economic incentives for airlines to invest in cleaner technologies and operations.

Airline and Manufacturer Pledges

The industry has made some bold commitments that seemed impossible just a few years ago:

United Airlines: Net zero by 2050 without relying on traditional carbon offsets

Airbus: Hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft in service by 2035

Boeing: Commercial aircraft and services compatible with 100% SAF by 2030

Delta Air Lines: $1 billion investment in carbon neutrality initiatives over 10 years

JetBlue: Net zero emissions by 2040—10 years ahead of the industry target

Rolls-Royce: All new aircraft engines compatible with 100% SAF by 2023

Role of Governments

Governments are stepping up with both carrots and sticks to accelerate aviation sustainability. The EU's RefuelEU Aviation regulation mandates minimum SAF blending starting at 2% in 2025 and ramping to 70% by 2050. The US Inflation Reduction Act provides tax credits for SAF production, making it more economically viable for producers.

R&D funding is flowing into breakthrough technologies: NASA's Advanced Air Mobility program is investing hundreds of millions in electric and hydrogen aircraft development. The European Union's Clean Aviation partnership has committed €4.1 billion to sustainable aviation technologies through 2030.

Conclusion

Here are the three key takeaways that matter most for aviation's sustainable future:

SAF is the near-term game-changer: Despite current production challenges, it's the most viable path to significant emissions reductions before 2035

Operational optimization delivers immediate wins: Quantum-powered simulation tools and AI-driven flight management are already reducing fuel consumption today

Long-term solutions require coordinated investment: Electric and hydrogen aircraft show promise, but success depends on infrastructure development and regulatory support

The aviation industry is moving faster toward sustainability than most people realize, but the challenges are still enormous.

title: Opportunity for India to become a major sustainable aviation fuel hub, says IATA's Preeti Jain
description:
Having earlier worked in this domain in India, how do you see the country’s SAF ecosystem?
There is enough ethanol supply in the country, and some of it can be diverted to make SAF… India wants to export ethanol, and similarly, SAF also presents a similar opportunity.
They provided production-linked incentives, they subsidised the feedstock, gave other incentives that led to the SAF feedstock supply chain being streamlined there, etc.
Then there were tax credits for SAF production and blending.
We need the same story in the SAF ecosystem.
text:
Having earlier worked in this domain in India, how do you see the country’s SAF ecosystem?

I have witnessed this ecosystem for more than 10 years in India. I’d say India is headed in the right direction and should do fine in meeting the initial requirements. Interestingly, India wants to come up with its tailor-made policies which can help its own ecosystem. The country has announced its intent to have time-bound SAF blending targets. But we are yet to see a firm roadmap and the implementation plan. Various Indian energy companies are working on SAF projects. These companies have always come forward to do what is required by the government and international commitments. So, I’m positive about India. The question is would India be happy just doing the bare minimum to meet mandates and requirements? Or does it want to be ahead of the curve and start making SAF not just for Indian airlines, but also for international airlines operating to India? There is enough ethanol supply in the country, and some of it can be diverted to make SAF… India wants to export ethanol, and similarly, SAF also presents a similar opportunity. There can be a ‘make in India for the world’ opportunity in SAF. India can potentially manufacture 40 million tonnes of SAF by 2050.

What is it that India should do to meet SAF requirements as well as become an SAF manufacturing hub?

India should prioritise feedstock for the production of SAF without waiting further, leverage the existing refining capability, invest in the research and innovation and new technologies. Funding should be made available to projects as well as the feedstock aggregation supply chains. It also needs to be ensured that the SAF manufactured in India meets all sustainability certification criteria, and that needs to start now, not when the plants are ready for production.

Europe already has SAF blending mandates which have come much before CORSIA’s mandatory phase kicks in (from 2027). Is it a move in the right direction?

Mandates and incentives need to come together in the right proportion. While there is already a mandate in Europe, the fundamental question is about the ecosystem, is it ready? That ecosystem readiness was not there, and in such a scenario, mandates aren’t going to really be effective. Much of the SAF being used in Europe is coming from different continents. Does it even make sense, considering long-haul transportation of the fuel itself would have a high carbon footprint? That is why we are asking for incentives to be brought in so that the local ecosystem is prepared with enough domestic production.

Why does IATA seem to be opposed to the way Europe is going about SAF mandates?

What airlines are being charged for SAF in Europe is not on a cost-plus basis. They are being charged exorbitant compliance fees and there is no transparency in the cost structure. We don’t understand what is the rationale behind these high numbers. We estimate that this non-transparent compliance fee is adding an additional $1.7 billion to the cost of SAF for airlines in Europe on top of the cost of SAF, which itself is quite high. It was already a supply-constrained market and then you (Europe) introduced mandates, which essentially means that the airline is bound to buy SAF at any price, or be penalised…Also, our position on SAF is that it should be feedstock agnostic and technology neutral. All technologies should compete, and the market forces would lead to the best and the most efficient ones being picked up. But Europe has put a sub-mandate for the power-to-liquid (PTL) pathway for SAF production. That puts other pathways and technologies (like alcohol-to-jet, which various companies are working on) at a disadvantage.

Unlike what is happening in Europe, the US is seen as a success story on SAF use. What did they do differently?

The US provided incentives around the value chain. In one sense, Europe and the US are very similar, in that they provided a lot of funding and research for these technologies to mature. But the US went a step ahead. They provided production-linked incentives, they subsidised the feedstock, gave other incentives that led to the SAF feedstock supply chain being streamlined there, etc. Then there were tax credits for SAF production and blending. Additionally, apart from the central or federal incentives, some US states also had their own incentive plans. Many of the SAF facilities also need hydrogen, so the US also provided some incentives for green hydrogen production. Essentially, they worked on bits and pieces across the SAF value chain.

Are US-like incentives the answer for boosting SAF production? Is it something that can easily be replicated in other parts of the world?

There is enough biorefinery capacity around the world. The question is, how can governments provide the right incentives for these biorefineries to switch their production in the favour of SAF. A biorefinery is not built specifically for renewable diesel or SAF for that matter. These capacities can swing very quickly to produce SAF. We can have sufficient production of SAF to meet the airlines’ demand—voluntary as well as the mandates. Governments should seriously look at incentives for SAF production, like facilitating offtake, providing subsidies, etc… Let’s take the example of solar and wind in India and elsewhere. Governments provided production-linked incentives, tax holidays, and subsidies. We need the same story in the SAF ecosystem.

title: AM Green to Acquire ORIX's Stake in Greenko Energy Holdings - ChemAnalyst
description:
AM Green BV (AMG), a prominent player in the clean energy space, has entered into definitive agreements to acquire a 17.5% equity stake in Greenko Energy Holdings (Greenko) from Japan-based ORIX Corporation.
This move allows ORIX to maintain long-term exposure to emerging green sectors such as green hydrogen, green ammonia, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and other next-generation low-carbon molecules.
Greenko operates over 10 gigawatts (GW) of renewable and pumped storage assets and is known for its innovation in large-scale energy storage.
In addition to its energy storage and renewable generation capabilities, AM Green has set ambitious targets for the production of green fuels.
Construction of its first green ammonia project, with a 1 MTPA capacity, is already underway in Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh.
text:
AM Green BV (AMG), a prominent player in the clean energy space, has entered into definitive agreements to acquire a 17.5% equity stake in Greenko Energy Holdings (Greenko) from Japan-based ORIX Corporation. The acquisition will be executed through AMG’s wholly owned subsidiary, AM Green Power BV (AMG Power). Following the completion of this transaction, expected in July 2025, AMG, including the stake held by its promoters, will collectively hold approximately 25% of Greenko’s equity.

In parallel with this equity transaction, ORIX has also agreed to invest in a convertible note issued by AM Green (Luxembourg) S.à.r.l (AMG Lux), which is the parent entity that owns 100% of AMG. This move allows ORIX to maintain long-term exposure to emerging green sectors such as green hydrogen, green ammonia, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and other next-generation low-carbon molecules. The investment is aligned with ORIX’s capital recycling strategy and broader focus on sustainable development.

Commenting on the development, Anil Chalamalasetty, Founder and CEO of AM Green, said, “This transaction is a significant milestone toward building one of the world’s most fully integrated and scalable green energy platforms. We thank ORIX for their ongoing partnership and confidence in our long-term vision.”

The deal enhances AM Green’s upstream integration capabilities through its strengthened partnership with Greenko, one of India’s largest renewable energy companies. Greenko operates over 10 gigawatts (GW) of renewable and pumped storage assets and is known for its innovation in large-scale energy storage. The company is currently developing what is expected to be the world’s largest “Intelligent Energy Storage Cloud Platform,” which will offer more than 100 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of daily storage capacity by 2030.

In addition to its energy storage and renewable generation capabilities, AM Green has set ambitious targets for the production of green fuels. The company plans to produce 5 million tonnes per annum (MTPA) of green ammonia. Construction of its first green ammonia project, with a 1 MTPA capacity, is already underway in Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh. Furthermore, the company is also advancing projects related to green hydrogen (targeting 1 MTPA capacity), sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and low-carbon products such as caustic soda, ethanol, and high-value bio-based chemicals. These efforts are being supported by AMG’s proprietary Chempolis technology.

With this acquisition and strategic investment from ORIX, AM Green is well-positioned to accelerate the development of its next-generation clean energy platform and reinforce its leadership in the global transition to sustainable fuels.

title: SAF Bill: Future-proofing the UK's e-SAF production - Transport & Environment
description:
To reduce aviation emissions, Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) has a key immediate role to play, alongside other longer-term measures.
UK and global SAF production remains extremely limited, increasing the risk of missing mandate targets, according to the Climate Change Committee.
Roger Tyers, T&E UK’s Aviation Policy Manager advised, "The UK Government's Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) bill is a welcome world-first.
It will create a revenue certainty mechanism, which will be vital to create investor confidence and kick-start domestic SAF production.
Consider e-SAF production as a key energy-intensive industry, as outlined in the recent industrial strategy, and eligible to benefit from lower electricity costs.
text:
To reduce aviation emissions, Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) has a key immediate role to play, alongside other longer-term measures. SAF covers a range of lower-carbon alternatives to conventional aviation kerosene. Unlike hydrogen or battery powered aircraft, SAF can be used immediately in existing aircraft as a ‘drop in’ fuel, without needing to adapt fuel delivery infrastructure.

To support the shift to SAF, the UK Government has already created a SAF mandate. From January 2025, this requires fuel suppliers to use a minimum proportion of SAF in the UK aviation fuel mix, rising from 2% in 2025 to 10% in 2030 and 22% in 2040.

UK and global SAF production remains extremely limited, increasing the risk of missing mandate targets, according to the Climate Change Committee. Major oil companies remain largely absent from the sector, which is dominated by start-up projects often viewed as high-risk by private investors. To address these barriers, , the UK Government introduced the Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill to parliament in May 2025.

The bill will create a ‘revenue certainty mechanism’ (RCM) to provide financial reassurance to investors in UK SAF plants, by creating a guaranteed price for SAF, known as the strike price. If the market price falls below this strike price, the SAF producer receives a top-up payment to cover the difference. Conversely, if the market price exceeds the strike price, the producer pays back the difference. The RCM is the first of its kind in the world and is a welcome innovation, especially as it will be funded by a levy on fuel suppliers under the ‘polluter pays’ principle, rather than by taxpayers.

However, not all SAF types are equally sustainable or scalable; government legislation should reflect this.

E-SAF—synthetic fuel made from air-captured carbon and renewable hydrogen—has the greatest decarbonisation potential, cutting lifecycle emissions by over 90% and avoiding land-use impacts and feedstock constraints of other SAFs. Only e-SAF can meet long-term aviation demand sustainably and at scale.

Roger Tyers, T&E UK’s Aviation Policy Manager advised, "The UK Government's Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) bill is a welcome world-first. It will create a revenue certainty mechanism, which will be vital to create investor confidence and kick-start domestic SAF production.

The Government must now earmark part of the revenue support toward the production of synthetic e-SAF - the most scalable and sustainable form of SAF. This will be good for energy security, economic growth, exports and UK jobs in the production of a fuel of the future. Otherwise there is a real risk that RCM funding will flow only to less sustainable biofuel projects."

UK and EU airline mandates will soon drive demand for e-SAF. With global competition expected for limited supply, imports alone won’t suffice. The RCM offers a chance to secure UK-produced e-SAF, helping meet both domestic targets and international demand. Since the UK currently imports over 60% of its jet fuel, domestic e-SAF production could retain value and reduce dependency on foreign petrostates.

The ensure the RCM is effective, the government should implement the following measures:

Amend the SAF bill so that it explicitly commits a proportion of RCM support to e-SAF projects - at least enough to enable production to meet the SAF Mandate e-SAF quota of around 65,000 tonnes of e-SAF in 2030, equating to one large plant.

Consider e-SAF production as a key energy-intensive industry, as outlined in the recent industrial strategy, and eligible to benefit from lower electricity costs.

In June 2025, over 130 organisations—including T&E, NGOs, investors, and e-SAF producers—signed a joint appeal urging the government to use the RCM to back e-SAF production. This would secure the UK a ‘first mover’ advantage, boost energy security, and support jobs and exports. Without such support, the bill and RCM risk being a significant missed opportunity.

text:
Airlines operating in Mexico transported 51.3 million passengers on regular flights between January and May 2025, reflecting a 3.7% year-over-year increase, according to the Federal Civil Aviation Agency (AFAC). This growth outpaces the 2.2% growth increase recorded during the same period in 2024.

The domestic market drove the rebound, with passenger numbers rising 5.4% to 25.5 million. This follows a 3.9% decline in 2024 due to the temporary grounding of Volaris and VivaAerobus aircraft for engine inspections.

In contrast, international carriers saw minimal growth, with a 0.4% increase to 18.5 million passengers. Traffic in the US–Mexico market declined by 4.4%, tempering the 6% growth seen in 2024.

Aeroméxico expanded its international operations, carrying 7.1 million passengers abroad—a 6.9% year-over-year increase. The airline plans to launch a new Mexico City–Philadelphia route in collaboration with Delta Air Lines.

Domestically, Volaris led in total passengers from January to May, transporting 11.3 million. Viva followed closely with 11.1 million and Aeroméxico ranked third with 9.8 million passengers. However, in May, Viva surpassed Volaris for the first time, carrying 2.3 million passengers compared to Volaris’ 2.2 million.

“Passenger traffic remained stable, with a resilient load factor of 84.8%, supported by ongoing efforts to optimize our route network and capacity,” said Viva CEO Juan Carlos Zuazua in the airline’s May operational report.

AFAC data highlighted the busiest domestic routes:

Mexico City–Cancun

Monterrey–Mexico City

Mexico City–Guadalajara

Tijuana–Mexico City

Tijuana–Guadalajara

Four routes experienced declines of 2.4% to 4.6%, while Tijuana–Guadalajara grew by 5.1%.

Internationally, the top routes were:

Toronto–Cancun (+34.1%)

Mexico City–Madrid (+1.1%)

Dallas/Fort Worth–Cancún

Los Angeles–Guadalajara

Chicago–Cancun (-19.2%).

AFAC forecasts that total air passenger numbers in Mexico will reach approximately 123 million by the end of 2025.

On June 10, Jesús Antonio Esteva Medina, Ministry of Infrastructure, Communications, and Transport (SICT), announced an expected 3%–5% growth in Mexico’s air transport sector during the current administration. A key initiative driving this growth is the adoption of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), which aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 50%–80% and create over 3,500 jobs. The first SAF-powered flight is scheduled for late 2025, with broader implementation in 2027.

Despite ongoing supply chain disruptions, constrained capacity has led to higher load factors, increased fares, and improved profitability for some airlines, according to John Grant, chief analyst, OAG.

The International Air Transport Association (IATA) projects US$36 billion in global airline profits for 2025, with a net margin of 3.7%. While still low for a capital-intensive industry, the outlook is bolstered by steady growth in Latin America, driven largely by low-cost carriers.

Grant noted that, despite global economic uncertainty and a forecasted slowdown in GDP growth from 3.3% in 2024 to 2.5% in 2025, the aviation industry’s performance in the first half of 2025 has exceeded expectations. Strong third-quarter results are anticipated, supported by cost savings and financial stability.

The new rules will oblige airlines to use sufficient SAF in international flights involving Turkiye to meet the 5 per cent emissions reduction goal.
They will also require jet fuel suppliers in the country to procure SAF to meet that target, and domestic oil refiners, Tupras and Socar to start producing SAFs.

text:
Turkiye will set mandates for airlines and jet fuel suppliers to boost uptake of sustainable aviation fuel, with a goal of reducing aviation emissions by 5 per cent by 2030, its civil aviation authority said on its website. The move is aimed at complying with the U.N. International Civil Aviation Organization's emission reduction scheme that will become mandatory in 2027.

The new rules will oblige airlines to use sufficient SAF in international flights involving Turkiye to meet the 5 per cent emissions reduction goal. They will also require jet fuel suppliers in the country to procure SAF to meet that target, and domestic oil refiners, Tupras and Socar to start producing SAFs.

Advt

The authority will publish minimum emission reduction targets before the end of the third quarter each year, it said, adding it would penalise airlines and jet fuel suppliers for any non-compliance.

Airline operators must load 90 per cent of the SAF they need for international flights in Turkiye , the authority said.

Aviation is responsible for 2.5 per cent of global energy-related CO2 emissions, according to the International Energy Agency. Tupras, Turkiye 's largest oil refiner, aims to produce 20,000 metric tons of SAF at one of its major plants in 2026, the company said earlier this year. It aims to lift production up to 400,000 tons by building a new unit at its Izmir refinery, pending a final investment decision.

DB Tarimsal Enerji, a local biofuel firm, also aims to produce 100,000 tons of SAF at a new plant. Turkiye 's jet fuel demand fell 4 per cent last year to 6.26 million tons, or 135,000 barrels per day, according to the country's energy regulator.

The move aligns with the United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization’s (ICAO) global emissions reduction plan, which will become mandatory in 2027.
Jet fuel producers in Turkey, including Tupras and Socar, will be required to begin SAF production.
Local biofuel company DB Tarimsal Enerji also plans to build a new facility to produce 100,000 tons of SAF.

text:
Istanbul: Turkey is preparing to introduce new rules requiring airlines and jet fuel suppliers to increase the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), aiming to reduce aviation-related carbon emissions by 5% by 2030, the country’s civil aviation authority announced on its website, reports Reuters.

The move aligns with the United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization’s (ICAO) global emissions reduction plan, which will become mandatory in 2027. Under the new guidelines, airlines operating international flights involving Turkey will be required to use enough SAF to meet the 5% reduction target. Fuel suppliers and oil refiners will also be expected to play their part.

Jet fuel producers in Turkey, including Tupras and Socar, will be required to begin SAF production. Tupras, the country’s largest oil refiner, plans to start producing 20,000 metric tons of SAF in 2026 and aims to scale up to 400,000 tons with the construction of a new unit at its Izmir refinery, pending a final investment decision. Local biofuel company DB Tarimsal Enerji also plans to build a new facility to produce 100,000 tons of SAF.

According to the civil aviation authority, a minimum share of SAF must be loaded within Turkey—airline operators will be required to load 90% of their SAF for international flights at Turkish airports. Fuel suppliers that fail to meet the new targets will face penalties, the authority added.

The aviation sector is currently responsible for about 2.5% of global energy-related CO₂ emissions, according to the International Energy Agency. Turkey’s push toward SAF comes amid a broader effort to reduce emissions and align with international environmental standards. The country’s jet fuel demand dropped by 4% last year to 6.26 million tons, or about 135,000 barrels per day, according to national energy data.

The aviation authority said it will publish updated minimum emission reduction targets before the end of each third quarter, keeping the industry informed and accountable as the SAF mandate progresses.

title: SAS places record order for 55 E195-E2 to power growth and regional connectivity
description:
The first aircraft deliveries from Embraer are scheduled to begin in late 2027, with further deliveries extending over approximately four years.
“The Embraer E195-E2 is a world-class aircraft, combining outstanding performance with excellent fuel efficiency and comfort.
This aircraft is key to enabling future growth and improved connectivity across Scandinavia and beyond.
Built for the future of sustainable aviation “The E2 is central to our strategy to build a modern, efficient fleet with strong performance.
SAS continues to strengthen its overall network and international reach while enhancing connectivity between regional cities and global destinations through more seamless and sustainable operations.
text:
Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) has entered into an agreement to acquire 45 Embraer (NYSE: ERJ; B3: EMBR3) E195-E2 aircraft, with purchase rights for an additional 10 aircraft — the largest SAS jet order direct from a manufacturer since 1996. This milestone agreement supports SAS’ long-term fleet renewal strategy, which is focused on increasing efficiency, reducing emissions, and unlocking future growth opportunities from its global hub in Copenhagen as well as across its Scandinavian and international network.

The first aircraft deliveries from Embraer are scheduled to begin in late 2027, with further deliveries extending over approximately four years. Excluding purchase rights, the value for the order is approximately US$4 billion.

“This is a defining moment for SAS,” says Anko van der Werff, President & CEO, SAS. “The Embraer E195-E2 is a world-class aircraft, combining outstanding performance with excellent fuel efficiency and comfort. This aircraft is key to enabling future growth and improved connectivity across Scandinavia and beyond. We’ve taken the time to make the right decision — and this major investment reflects our confidence in the future and the strength of the agreement we’ve secured.”

The E195-E2 will play a vital role in optimizing SAS’ operations and enhancing connectivity across Scandinavia and Europe. Its size and range are ideally suited to complement SAS’ existing fleet and route structure, allowing for more frequencies, better network flexibility, and lower trip costs.

Built for the future of sustainable aviation

“The E2 is central to our strategy to build a modern, efficient fleet with strong performance. It enables us to serve more routes with lower emissions, better economics, and a premium experience for our passengers,” adds Van der Werff. “Together with Embraer, we are setting the course for the next chapter of SAS.”

The E2 family of aircraft has already been tested with 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and is in the process of being fully certified to fly on 100% SAF in the foreseeable future. Today blends of up to 50% SAF are already achievable.

Arjan Meijer, President and CEO Embraer Commercial Aviation, says: “We are thrilled to deepen our partnership with SAS through this landmark deal. The E2 is the quietest single aisle jet available today – 29% more fuel efficient and with a 62% reduction in noise footprint over the previous generation jet, the E195-E2 is a game-changer in terms of efficiency, performance, and passenger comfort. We are confident that these aircraft will play a crucial role in SAS’ fleet renewal and expansion strategy, supporting their ambitious growth plans and enhancing their operational capabilities.”

Powered by Pratt & Whitney’s advanced PW1900G GTF engines, the E195-E2 delivers double-digit reductions in fuel burn, emissions, and noise compared to previous-generation aircraft. The new fleet will help lower SAS’ environmental footprint and reinforce its position as a driving force in reducing aviation’s climate impact.

This order marks another step in SAS’ future-focused transformation, supporting a modernized fleet and improved travel experience. SAS continues to strengthen its overall network and international reach while enhancing connectivity between regional cities and global destinations through more seamless and sustainable operations.

This order was facilitated by the support of Skyworks Holding.

SAS was recently ranked as the world’s most punctual airline*, a testament to the company’s commitment to operational excellence and reliability.

*SAS ranked No. 1 out of 660 airlines globally for on-time performance in April and May 2025 (source: Cirium).

text:
Willis Lease Finance Corporation (NASDAQ: WLFC) has executed a bold strategic move by divesting its consultancy arm, Bridgend Asset Management Limited (BAML), into its joint venture Willis Mitsui & Co. Engine Support Limited (WMES). This transaction, finalized in June 2025, represents a critical pivot to amplify WLFC's role in aviation asset management while leveraging its partnership with Mitsui & Co., Ltd. The integration of BAML's technical expertise into WMES's operations could position the joint venture as a dominant player in global MRO (Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul) markets, backed by a growing $380 million asset base.

The Strategic Rationale: Synergies and Scale

WLFC's decision to transfer BAML to WMES is a calculated play to consolidate its aviation services under a single, robust platform. By merging BAML's records management and technical consultancy with WMES's engine leasing and maintenance capabilities, the joint venture gains a full-suite offering for aviation clients. This vertical integration eliminates redundancies, streamlines operations, and enhances WMES's ability to compete in high-margin MRO services—a sector projected to grow at 5% annually through 2030.

The $45 million sale price for BAML, subject to working capital adjustments, injects liquidity into WLFC's balance sheet. This capital can be redirected toward high-potential initiatives, such as expanding its engine leasing fleet or advancing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) projects through its subsidiary, Willis Sustainable Fuels. Meanwhile, the renamed Willis Mitsui & Co. Asset Management Limited (WAML) will serve as WMES's technical backbone, enabling the joint venture to expand into markets like Asia and Europe, where demand for engine-related services is surging.

Financial and Operational Leverage

WLFC's ownership stake in WMES remains at 50%, ensuring it benefits directly from the joint venture's growth. WMES's current $380 million asset base—a figure expected to rise as WAML's expertise drives new deals—provides a solid foundation for scaling. Notably, WLFC's subsidiary, Willis Engine Structured Trust VIII, recently issued $596 million in asset-backed notes secured by 64 engines/airframes. This financing highlights the company's confidence in the underlying demand for aviation infrastructure.

Risks and Considerations

While the transaction is strategically sound, risks persist. Geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures, and oil price volatility could disrupt lessee compliance and asset valuations. Additionally, WLFC's Q1 2025 earnings missed EPS estimates, signaling potential operational headwinds. Insider trading data further raises eyebrows: executives, including CEO Austin Willis, sold over $10 million in shares in the past six months. While this could reflect personal financial decisions, it may also indicate caution about near-term volatility.

The Investment Thesis: Capitalizing on Undervalued Aviation Infrastructure

Despite these risks, WLFC's move into integrated aviation asset management aligns with sector tailwinds. As airlines and lessors increasingly prioritize cost efficiency and sustainability, WMES's expanded capabilities position it to capture a larger share of the $50 billion MRO market. Analysts at JPMorgan estimate that WMES could grow its asset base to $500 million by 2027, driven by WAML's technical services and Mitsui's global reach.

Investors should note that WLFC's stock trades at a discount to peers, with a P/B ratio of 1.2x compared to the sector average of 1.5x. This undervaluation, combined with WMES's growth potential, makes WLFC an attractive entry point for contrarian investors. The company's focus on sustainable aviation fuels and engine leasing—both key to decarbonizing aviation—also aligns with ESG trends, enhancing its long-term appeal.

Conclusion: A Strategic Play for Long-Term Gains

Willis Lease Finance Corporation's integration of BAML into WMES is a strategic masterstroke that strengthens its foothold in aviation asset management. While risks such as macroeconomic volatility remain, the transaction's synergies, liquidity injection, and Mitsui's backing suggest a compelling upside. Investors seeking exposure to undervalued aviation infrastructure plays should consider adding WLFC to their portfolios, particularly if they're willing to ride out short-term uncertainty for long-term growth.

Recommendation: Buy WLFC with a 12–18 month horizon, targeting a price target of $28–32 (vs. current ~$24) as WMES's asset base expands and MRO demand accelerates.

We thank Sen. Chuck Grassley and Finance Chair Mike Crapo for their work on this measure.” About the SABR Coalition Sustainable Advanced Biofuel Refiners (SABR) is a coalition of stakeholders that have invested in building out America’s first advanced biofuel—biodiesel.
text:
Sustainable Advanced Biofuel Refiners successful in getting short-term transitional relief for biodiesel producers in Senate budget-reconciliation bill.

Finding some transitional relief in 2025 has been SABR’s top priority.”

— Joe Jobe, CEO, Sustainable Advanced Biofuel Refiners (SABR) Coalition

JEFFERSON CITY, MO, UNITED STATES, July 1, 2025 /EINPresswire.com/ -- The Sustainable Advanced Biofuel Refiners (SABR) Coalition, a national biodiesel trade association made up of over 70 organizational members throughout the biodiesel value chain, applauds the biofuel provisions added to the Senate budget-reconciliation legislation known as the “big, beautiful bill.” Introduced on June 28, the Senate version of the tax bill includes provisions for an immediate extension of the Section 40A Small Agri-Biodiesel Producer Tax Credit. The value of the credit increases from 10 cents to 20 cents per gallon on the first 15 million gallons. It also makes the credit transferable so that pass-through entities such as limited liability companies (LLCs) and S corporations can access the credit and monetize it. This is important transitional relief to biodiesel producers, many of which have shut down this year since the biodiesel blenders tax credit (BTC) expired on Dec. 31, 2024, while the industry awaits implementing regulations for its replacement, the Clean Fuel Production Credit (Section 45Z).

“Finding some transitional relief in 2025 has been SABR’s top priority,” said SABR CEO Joe Jobe.

The Senate bill also introduces several key improvements to Section 45Z, which will take effect in 2026. Some changes mirror those passed by the House of Representatives on May 22 while others differ significantly. The differences must be reconciled before the legislation can be sent to President Donald Trump for signing into law by the July 4 target date.

Like the House revisions, these improvements by the Senate include elimination of the failed theory of indirect land-use change (ILUC) that penalizes domestic agricultural feedstocks in modeling greenhouse gas (GHG) calculations.

A critical difference between the Senate’s modifications to 45Z and both existing law and changes passed by the House is that the Senate version seeks to put sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and on-road biofuels such as biodiesel and renewable diesel on equal footing. Currently, SAF producers are eligible for up to $1.75 per gallon under Section 45Z, provided certain criteria are met, but biodiesel manufacturers can only receive up to a maximum of $1 per gallon.

While the House bill extends Section 45Z from its current sunset date of Dec. 31, 2027, to Dec. 31, 2031, the Senate version shortens this extension by two years and allows transferability of the credit through 2029.

Earlier modifications to Section 45Z from the Senate Finance Committee allowed feedstocks from outside the U.S. to claim the credit at a 20 percent discount to domestic inputs. Updated language in the full Senate bill, however, matches the House version and only allows feedstocks from North America to qualify for the incentive.

SABR reiterates that, because these changes do not take effect until 2026, it is important that Congress provides transitional relief now as a policy bridge to 2026.

“The amendments to the Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit will make for dramatically better energy, agriculture and clean transportation policy,” Jobe said. “But those amendments take effect in 2026, and SABR has been educating members of Congress about the severe immediate harm to the biodiesel industry caused by the lack of policy clarity. SABR has been urging immediate extension of the Section 40A Small Agri-Biodiesel Producer Tax Credit and applauds its inclusion. While most biofuel advocates have been focused solely on ‘fixing’ 45Z beginning next year in the reconciliation bill, a top priority for SABR has been getting transitional relief for biodiesel producers this year. We thank Sen. Chuck Grassley and Finance Chair Mike Crapo for their work on this measure.”

About the SABR Coalition

Sustainable Advanced Biofuel Refiners (SABR) is a coalition of stakeholders that have invested in building out America’s first advanced biofuel—biodiesel. Biodiesel is the most cost-effective means to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from medium- and heavy-duty vehicles, providing numerous economic, environmental and energy security benefits. It is produced from renewable resources such as soybean oil, used cooking oil and animal fats. SABR includes stakeholders from every link in the value chain from feedstock growers to biodiesel producers, distributors, retailers and consumers, as well as infrastructure, product and service providers. For more information, please visit www.sabrcoalition.org.
